instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD: What is PP0V9_SSD? PP0V9_SSD is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .
definitions.PP2V7_NAND: What is PP2V7_NAND? PP2V7_NAND is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Clean board I get 20V on charger and 12.6V on PPBUS, here are some more measurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.63V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.79V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.19V
<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>P3V3MAIN_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 3.26V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> = 1.8 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 5.4V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v

I also tried restoring T2 on both Catalina and Big Sur and got error 9 something....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
As you get all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages, machine should enter into DFU.
Check SSD voltages too.

Inspect audio board for liquid sign, on both sides.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Board does enter DFU, but fails to restore/revive in both Catalina and Big Sur
Audio board is clean and flex too.

<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND</SIGNAL> = 2.5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL> = 0.9V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 1.8V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
There could be a problem with T2 then.
Did you check for short on all big coils?
No pulse at all on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, when trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
No shorts on any of the bog coils.

<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is 12.6V how do I trigger it, sorry for the novice question.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> should not be 12.6v!!!!!! You are measuring wrong, or you have a very bad problem somewhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message: Thats what I was suspecting, I was expecting 1.8v or so on that rail, I will check PMU now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
My bad, I was measuring in the wrong place.

When I trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> doesn't pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message: I can reball T2 no problem, but if that doesn't solve the issue can the T2 chip be replaced from a donor board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
The client said something about how the fault appeared?
Did you try with known good battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message: This machines come from other shops with very little to no details.
